description: Borrowed from Middle French imposer (“to lay on, impose”), taking the place of Latin imponere (“to lay on, impose”), from in (“on, upon”) +‎ ponere (“to put, place”).

verbs.description: impose (third-person singular simple present imposes, present participle imposing, simple past and past participle imposed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To establish or apply by authority.
(intransitive) to be an inconvenience (on or upon)
examples: I don't wish to impose upon you.

entries.meaning: to enforce: compel to behave in a certain way
To practice a trick or deception (on or upon).
To lay on, as the hands, in the religious rites of confirmation and ordination.
To arrange in proper order on a table of stone or metal and lock up in a chase for printing; said of columns or pages of type, forms, etc.
